ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned how to better communicate my scientific projects, which will prove very useful as I move into my senior year and start preparing for my year-long thesis. I also learned about different laboratory techniques, from Sanger sequencing to single-cell multiomics to even PCR reactions.
Biology laboratory techniques.
I improved my research and presentation skills dramatically. I also learned a lot about relevant biotechnologies and was able to conduct significant research in the DiMaio lab.

Learned how to effectively organize information related to my research and how to communicate that information via writing and speaking. Also learned a lot about research technologies and resources yale has related to molecular research
I learned about fundamental research technologies and techniques. Additionally, I learned how to better present my scientific research both orally and in written format.
Presentation skills and lab work.

Practice with scientific communication, ranging from good record keeping in lab notebooks, oral presentations, writing proposals, and providing critical feedback to peers. Workshops also provided valuable information on Yale's library, informatics, and geospatial resources. Lectures on molecular biology techniques also provided general background knowledge on the techniques available and how they work.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: While it was really interesting to learn about different laboratory techniques, I was under the impression that this course's primary purpose was to teach us how to write our research proposals for our senior thesis and this course did not do this. We had one Background and Significance assignment that we did not receive feedback on and we rarely talked about the end of semester proposal assignment. While we worked on our presenting skills much more after spring break, which was quite helpful, and we received more in-class feedback, I often felt lost in the course and I think more timely feedback would have alleviated this.

I really loved the days in which we sat down and troubleshot our presentational skills and nerves. It was good to deconstruct what went well and what went poorly in our presentations, and I felt this helped me a lot when I had to plan my later two presentations. It was also interesting to learn about some of the technologies being used in molecular biology (the single-cell multi-omics was the most interesting to me), and I also liked when we had guest speakers come to introduce us to their research or new skills. One weakness was that there were not enough opportunities to discuss our research with each other as a class. The class was structured as either a 2-hour lecture or day of high-stakes presentations. It would have been nice to have something in between so that we could feel more comfortable answering questions and thinking about our research on the spot. It was also confusing what we had to turn in for grades, and what were meant to just be exercises for new skills.
The course is extremely disorganized. Also, some of the workshops seem boring and unnecessary.

Strengths: You will definitely become a better speaker and presenter. You get to meet a lot of students also in research. Dr. Moreno and Dr. Nelson are highly passionate about teaching and truly care about making you the best scientist you can be. Excellent for fulfilling lab course requirements for medical schools. 

Weaknesses: Assignments are graded very slowly and very rigorously. Additionally, the time commitment is very high; you complete class assignments, keep a comprehensive lab notebook, and do 8-10 hours of actual research every week. That translates to 4+ days of the week where you are investing a solid chunk of time into this class.

I think the strongest portion of the course was the public speaking components, as well as Dr. Morenos lectures regarding them. I wish we had more time to do more with this, as I found the focus on scientific communication the most useful. 

Some of the lectures, particularly the ones on techniques and technologies, did feel very long and I had a hard time concentrating and actually internalizing the information.
I think the class was good overall, I thought we didnt focus as much on the writing aspect of the proposal though
It was interesting and allowed for me to work in lab. There was not much feedback on assignments, so it was really hard to know what you were even being graded on or how to improve.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would definitely recommend this course if you want to feel more prepared for your senior thesis project. Not only that, but it does so much to build your confidence as a science communicator, and I feel like this class would help a lot for future careers in research.
Yes, if you need an MCDB lab.
I would recommend this course to any student interested in research in the biological sciences.

Yes, but not if you have significant research experience. I found it helpful as a newcomer to research, but it was somewhat discouraging when my classmates who have clearly been doing research for years presented their work, which was very obviously a culmination of years of work, and often made me feel like I wasnt doing a good enough job. I know this isnt true, but this class was marketed for juniors with little to no experience and I dont understand why some of my classmates were in this class at all.
I think this is a solid mcdb lab course
Yes, I would absolutely recommend this course if you are conducting research in the sciences and especially if you would like to improve your public presentation skills.
It is a good prep course for thesis.
